text: A quiet, upper-middle class, North Shore Chicago suburb. Chevy Blazer cruises slowly down the street. Morning Papers are pitched out the window. A dog runs between the houses. It's early autumn.

An attractive, old, three-story brick colonial. A news- paper flies into frame, strikes the corner of the house a drops into the bushes, a good twenty feet from the porch. An alarm clock goes off with a jarring bzzzzz!

The alarm continues for a beat. It stops and the house explodes with activity as the Baker family wakes and scrambles about their morning activities. There's Jim Baker, midforties, father, insurance executive, tall, lea somewhat meek-looking, in his suit pants and handlebar undershirt scurrying to the bathroom.

Let's go! Chop, chop! We've got relatives invading this afternoon! He slams’the bathroom door. His wife, Brenda, whips out o the bedroom in her housecoat and heads down the stairs. She's also in her midforties, strong, attractive and dominant. Mike Baker, ten, wanders out of his bedroom, . stratching his rear end, yawning. He's young trouble, preteen maniac boy.
(as she descends) Ginny! Mike! Sara! Sam!
(phoney, pained) Oh, God. I think I have a fever. Sara Baker, seven, comes out of her room. She's all sweetness and cutes.
You don't have a fever.
Why don't you shut your face?
Make me. Mike raises a fist. Sara shrieks.
Dad! Mike hit me!
_ You liar! The bathroom door opens and Jim comes out with a toothbru in his mouth.

(talks with the toothbrush in his mouth) Mike! Come on, pal, we're having a wedding tomorrow. Why can't you cooperate? Ginny Baker, twenty-one, comes out of her room in panties and a sweatshirt. She's very pretty, very pampered and very sloppy. She slips past Jim as he scolds Mike, goes into the bathroom and locks the door. Sara turns and marches into the bathroom at the other end of the hall.
Dad, I didn't hit her. I'd like to very much and I probably will later, but give me a break, you know my method. I don't hit her when you're just down the hall.
Pick on somebody your own size. He turns back to the bathroom. MIKE AND SARA ‘ 3-A She gives Mike a smug, snotty face. He squints angrily.
Later. Sara turns up her nose and goes back down the hall to the other bathroom.
discovers the bathroom door's locked. He rattles the knob
I was in there first! Open the door!
I'm so sure!
Ginny's standing in the shower with the water beating aga the side of her head.
I'm the one getting married, Daddy.
Not until tomorrow. Come on! I got a mouthful of toothpaste!
(to herself) What a pest. (to Jim) I happen to have a serious problem!
Jim growls angrily and gives up. He turns to see Mike leaning on the knewl post, eavesdropping.

(with a chuckle) ‘She has her period, Dad. (raises an eyebrow) Should make for an interesting honeymoon, huh? Jim looks at Mike, startled by the brash maturity of his remark. Mike trots down the stairs.
Where're you getting that mouth?
(matter-of- factly) School.
Brenda's making coffee, eggs, toast and school lunches al at the same time. Mike wanders in and turns on the TV and dials in cartoons. A bowl of cereal is waiting for him. He starts to eat. :
Is everybody up?
Yep. Jim walks in and crosses to the sink.
Nope. He spits in the sink. Brenda stares at him. She leans over and looks in the sink.
Thank you, dear. You just unloaded all over my luncheon.
A bowl of boiled shrimp covered with toothpaste.
Jim smiles sheepishly at Brenda. She turns on the water to rinse the shrimp.
Mike, make sure Sam gets up.
(shouts) Sara! Wake up Sam!
Sara's standing on a stool, bare-chested with an underarm lathered with shave cream. She's shaving her underarms with Jim's electric razor. ‘She turns it off, put-out wit the order to wake Sam. :
Jesus Christ! What am I? A slave? She opens the door.  10 11 12
Sara comes out of the bathroom, crosses to a door leading to a third floor staircase and yells.
Hey, Dorklips! Haul ass!

It's a girl's bedroom done in antiques and frills. In contrast to the mayhem on the first two floors, the third floor is quiet and serene. A brilliant shaft of morning sunlight shines down through a skylight above the brass bed. The sheets and blankets are rumpled and kicked aside Samantha Baker stands before a floor mirror in the corner of the room. Her back is to camera. A bath towel is wrapped around her waist. She's staring at her body in th mirror. She was up long before anyone else in the house _ and has already showered. She puts a hand on her hip an strikes a pose. She doesn't like it. She tries the other hand. Both hands. She cocks her hip. Finally, she raises both arms and strikes a Charles Atlas pose. She holds it for a moment, then drops her arms. She groans.
She's young and pretty. No seething, precocious sexuality Just a pretty, young girl. She's frowning. Obviously dis- pleased with her looks.
Chronologically, you're sixteen today. Physically, you're still fifteen. She lifts her damp hair off her face and neck and examine the effect. She's not pleased.
(drops the hair) Worthless. She reaches down, out of frame, and comes up with a telephone. .
(to the phone) I look exactly the same as I have since summer. Utterly forgettable.
She walks to a window seat and sits down. She pulls her knees up under her chin.

(pause, still looking in the mirror) No, I didn't expect to wake up trans- formed. I just thought that turning sixteen is so major I'd wake up with an improved mental state that would show on my face. All that shows is the fact that I don't have any tan left. (with a closing sigh) My family's probably pissed that I haven't come down to let them wish me ‘Happy Birthday'. I'll see you at school. She hangs up the phone.
I need four inches of bod and a great birthday.
Sam comes down the hall, buttoning her blouse. Jim comes out of the bedroom, dressed for work. She sees him and stops. She smiles, waiting for a “happy birthday" from hi
(bright, cheerful) Hi, Dad.

Hi, Sam. Better hurry. And that's it. No happy birthday. Sam is stunned. She watches him hurry down the stairs. The bathroom door open and Ginny comes out swaddled in bath towels. She sees Sam and sighs dramatically.
You know what today is?
Sam smiles and nods, expecting a birthday greeting from Ginny.
The first day of my all-new com- pletely screwed-up period. Are you on the pill? Sam's smile fades. She shakes her head slowly.
Then you'll probably have a great honeymoon. (to herself) This is such a deluxe bite. Ginny goes back into the bathroom and locks the door.
(to herself, sarcastically) Thank you. Yes, it is my birthday. How nice of you to remember.
Brenda herds Mike and Sara through the dining room and in the foyer. Jim comes in from the living room. He's fran- tically searching for his briefcase.
Where's my briefcase? He opens the closet and rummages around for the briefcase
Where'd you leave it?
Don't be a smart ass!
Okay, I'll be a dumb ass.
You already are.
(to Sara) Touche!
BRENDA (Cont'd) (to Jim) Where's Sam?
Where's my briefcase? He pulls out hockey sticks, coats, hats, boots, toys, but no briefcase.
(yells up the stairs) Sam!

(to Brenda) Allow me, Brenda. (yells) Hey! Birth defect! Sam comes down the stairs, dressed, with her books under her arm. She scowls at Mike and smiles at Brenda. Again, she's expecting a birthday greeting.
(to Sam) You missed breakfast again.
It wasn't my idea to give her her own phone line. I don't have my own phone line.
(to Sam) Grab a doughnut.
I wouldn't if I were you. Mike tongued all the powdered sugar off. They're totally infected. Jim kisses Brenda.
(to Jim) The grandparents'1ll be here this afternoon.
We're still going out tonight with the Rice Chex?
(corrects him) Rizezechs. Eight, at the club. And you'd better learn their names. As of tomorrow, they're family. Jim crosses to the door.
Lovely thought. (to Sam) When it comes time for you to get married, do us a favor, elope. Jim exits.
Who'd marry her?
Mr. T.
(kisses Sam's cheek) You'll have to buy lunch today. I didn't have time to do your carrots.
(laughs) She's eating carrots to increase the size of her breasts. Sam raises her fist. Brenda beats her to him and gives hi a solid shake.
You shape up, mister, or I swear to God you won't go to your sister's wedding!
Promise? Brenda draws back to hit him. He races out the door. Brenda kisses Sara and scoots her on her way. Sam stares at Brenda, giving her one last chance to mention her birthday.
Don't give me that pouty look of yours. You can eat your carrots when you get home.
That's it? You don't have anything else to say to me, today?
(weary) What would you like me to say, Sam? Come on, you'll miss the bus. Sam sighs and looks away.
Have a good day. Brenda exits. Sam stands alone in the foyer. She looks up at the ceiling, fighting off her tears.
(to herself, incredulous) I can't believe this. They fucking forgot my birthday. Theme music comes up.
A sprawling suburban high school. Roll credits over:

A -- Bus doors opening, young faces spilling out. B -- Every imaginable form of footwear scurrying past cam C -- Nervous fingers twirling a padlock combination and yanking on the stubborn lock. It doesn't open. D -- A pair of rumps, male and female. A male hand on the female rear, a female hand on the male. E -- The tops of a lot of boys' heads shrouded in cigaret smoke. F -- A girl's head from the brow up as she furiously fuss with her tresses. G -- Lips are painted animal pink.

A large study hall. A male teacher is at the head of the class grading papers. Sam's in the second seat from the back. Randy's directly behind her, slumped down in her chair with an open book propped up in front of her. She yawns. Sam's hunched over taking the sex test.

One seat behind Sam in the next row of desks is a tall, handsome senior, Jake Ryan. He's an athlete and a class officer. The most significant male in the entire student body. He's bored with the study hall and is staring at Sam. She's figuring somewhere in his daydream.
Sam turns the test sheet over and continues.
Her answer, "I DON'T THINK SO".
so" WOULD YOU EVER IF YOU
Sam thinks. It's a tough decision. She answers.
"I GUESS so"

head_text.subj: NAME'S NOT ON THIS SO IT'S

text: She's worried and nervous about answering the final ques- tion. She lowers her head and peeks under her arm at Jake 19 20 21 22
He's gnawing his thumbnail, still staring at Sam.
She blanches as Jake catches her looking at him. She clum tries to make it appear as if she's just scratching her c on her shoulder. She eurns back to her test.
Her hand's trembling as she slowly writes "JAKE RYAN" on question #9. Her hand glides down to the last question

head_text.subj: KNOW THAT YOU WANT TO WITH HIM

text: Sam writes a very definite, "NO!" and underlines it.
She carefully folds the test into a tiny square, palms it and pretending to yawn, puts her arms behind her head and drops the folded note on Randy's desk.
She's sound asleep in her seat, head back, mouth open. Sh doesn't see the note drop on her desk. Jake does.
The note slides down the sloped writing desk and off.
The note falls on the floor. Jake's hightop comes down on top of the note and slides it away.
He reaches down and retrieves the note. He holds it in hi palm and slips it in his pocket, keeping his eyes on Sam all the while.
Sam and Randy are walking down the hall. Sam's upset.
You swear to God you don't have it?
I don't know anything about it.
Nancy Ludwig gave me a sex test during Child Development and I was supposed to do it and pass it to you in independent study. Randy shrugs her shoulders. It's news to her.
(devastated) I'm totally screwed.
Did you put your name on it?
No, but it's really embarrassing. I had to name who I'd do it with if I ever did it. Randy can't wait to hear who Sam's dream lover is.
Who'd you name?
(hesitant) Jake Ryan.
(incredulous) Jake Ryan?! He doesn't even know you exist.
(hurt) That's a real nice thing to say.
Sorry. But Jake Ryan? He's a senior and he's taken. I mean really taken.
(agrees) I know. It was supposed to be my ideal.
He's ideal for sure but forget it.
God, I hope whoever got the note doesn't know it was me that wrote it. I'd shit twice and die. They continue down the hall.
It's loud and crowded. Jake's sitting on a window ledge. He takes Sam's note out of his pocket and reads it. obviously very interested. He turns the page.
Jake reads his name in Sam's hand.
He sits bolt upright. He looks left, then right, to make sure no one's seen the note or suspects him of anything.
Randy and Sam move their trays along the line. Sam's looking at her tray with revulsion.
I can't believe I'm actually going to consume a school hamburger.
They're not too terrible since they started using meat. What happened to your carrots?
Brenda was too busy today. If she can't remember my birthday, I can't expect her to remember my carrots.
Are they working?

tests his buddy's reaction to his developing feelings for Sam. The note and its intimate revelations have set off a fury of emotions in Jake and it's almost as though he's seeking approval for the way he feels. Rock is decidedly unromantic. Girls are sex, sex is sport, sport is life. One at a time, the boys rise up into frame, deliver their lines and drop. Until noted, only one boy is on screen at a time.
(cautiously) Do you know Samantha Baker?
Sophomore, right?
What do you think of her?
I don't.
Would you ever go out with her?
Depends on how much you paid me.
(takes offense) She's not ugly.
There's nothing there, man. It's not ugly. It's just...void, you know. Jake holds himself up and rests his chin on the bar. Rock pulls himself and holds alongside Jake.
There's something about her. I do Independant Study with her and I catch her looking at me a lot. It's kind of cool the way she's always looking at me.
Maybe she's retarded.
I'm being serious, okay? She looks at me like she's in love with me.
Rock stares at Jake like he's lost his mind. Tenderness i not Rock's forte.
Jake, she's a child.
So?
So, what are you going to do with her? She's too young to party serious.
Maybe I'm interested in more than a party.
You talk like you're hard-up. You got Caroline. She's a woman.
I been going with her for like a year and you know what? I don't think she loves me. And I don't think I love her.
(puzzled) What the hell does that have to do with anything?

I think about Caroline, you know, and I realize that I never think about her unless I'm with her and then all I'm thinking is how I never think about her. I look in her eyes and I see tits. I look at this other girl and I don't care about tits.
She doesn't have any.
(frustrated) Don't you understand what I'm saying?
I don't think you understand what you're saying. I mean, you can park your pecker wherever you want but I think you're nuts to eighty-six Caroline for some’ sophomore wimp ’ that looks at you weird.
I'm all fucked-up about this, Rock. (sighs) What's happening to me?

(worried) I don't know but I hope you're not turning gay. Jake grimaces. He lets go of the bar and walks away. We widen to reveal that the boys have been doing cheater's chin-ups on a five foot bar. Rock's puzzled and disturbed . by Jake's conversation.

Girls are showering and dressing after gym. We see Sam an Randy standing in the doorway of the shower room with the arms folded across their chests to conceal their modest charms. Sam's shaking her head as she studies the mature physiques of the senior girls. Randy clucks her tongue.
That's unbelievable. I swear to God, Caroline Mulford had to flunk about nine grades.
They hold their intense stares.
It truly makes me ill.
is showering in front of them. She looks about twenty-thr with a fully and perfectly developed body. Pin-up time. Her face is in the water spray and she doesn't realize sh being scrutinized. 39 40
Sam looks up from her chest. Randy breathes a pained sigh
She's perfect.
And practically impossible to cut up. She's supposedly real sweet, her brother's deaf and everybody in the world worships her.
And she's going with Jake. Randy looks at Sam sympathetically.
Figures, huh? Does she have a pink. Trans Am?
Black.
(with an exagerrated sigh) I'm gonna kill myself. A cloud of steam rolls across them and they disappear.
Freshmen boys are climbing on board. They're silly and rowdy, pushing and shoving. Sam and Randy move in the crowd of boys, all of them a good head shorter.
I loathe the bus.
Sam and Randy board the bus. The Bus Driver, who is dress like the weenie boys and wears a Walkman around his neck, is giving the high five to the boys boarding the bus.
Mah, man! Square it off.

He offers his hand to Sam. She regards it with a sneer. She and Randy take their seats. They're surrounded by dopey Freshmen boys in ugly sweaters and parkas. The dregs of school society. The only other girl on the bus is a weird introvert with a spinal correction neck brace. A couple of band members are practicing in the back. We hear hand-held computer games.
There has to be a more dignified mode of transportation.
I hope you get a car for your birthday. And a driver's license.
Let's not hold our breath. Sam and Randy focus on the seat in front of them.
On second thought.... They take deep breaths and hold their noses.
in the seat in front of them are turned around to face th They're smiling with disgusting mouthsful of braces and j straps on their heads. They raise electronic ray guns and fire at Sam and Randy.
Cars are parked in the driveway and on the street.
Brenda and Ginny are hosting their luncheon. Ginny has opened her gifts and is sitting with a wok in her lap.

(phoney) Aunt Grace, Rudy and I are just going to adore and enjoy the wok. Rudy's a freak for stir-fry stuff. It was a really neat thought. All of you, really. She sets the wok down along with ten other gift woks. She's received one from every luncheon guest.  49g 50
The school bus pulls up and stops. Randy climbs down. Sam speaks to her out the window.
Call me, okay?
You call me first and tell me what happened at home. ' _SAM ; I'll tell you right now. Nothing.
Quit feeling sorry for yourself. It's bad for your complexion. The bus pulls out.

It's just Sam the neck brace girl and one freshman weenie the Geek. He's skinny and small with a cheap haircut, an imitation LaCoste shirt, baggy Levi cords, tennis shoes w dark socks and a nylon backpack filled with books. He str down the aisle and sits next to Sam. .He gives her his se look -- calves' eyes and a metal-mouth smile.
How's it goin'?
(annoyed) How's what going?
You know, things. Life and whatnot.
Life is not whatnot and it's none of your business.
Are you going to the New Faces dance tonight?
That's also none of your business. The Geek puts his arm up on the back of the bus seat.
Sam looks 25 50
What's the story? You got a guy? at the Geek with an angry, threatening squint.
Three big ones and they lust for wimp blood. So, quit bugging me or I'll sic them all over your weenie ass.
I'm getting input from you that I'm reading as relatively hostile.
Fuck off!

Woo! Definitely hostile. What's the problem? I'ma he, you're a she. I'm attracted to you. I see you everyday. I think about you fre- quently. Is there something wrong with my trying to put together some kind of relationship? The bus stops. Sam gathers up her things. The Geek reaches out and takes her arm. Sam jerks
Just answer me one question.
Yes. You're a total fag.
That's not the question. her arm away.

(raises an eyebrow) Am I turning you on? Sam stares at the Geek for a moment, then hurries down th aisle of the bus and exits. He's confident that because she actually conversed with him, she likes him.
Encouraging, very encouraging.
The luncheon guests are saying their farewells and wishin the bride-to-be good luck.

Sam shuffles up the walk to the porch. The door opens and the ladies stream out. A couple smile at Sam, most don't recognize her. She stands to the side and plasters a polite grin on her face as she waits patiently for them t clear the door. Brenda and Ginny stand in the door and wave.
(phoney) Thank you so much. Thank you. You're all incredibly kind.
Thank you for coming.
I love the woks. Rudy's going to be so excited.
We'll see you all tomorrow! As soon as the ladies are out of earshot, Ginny leans against the doorjamb and groans.
I sincerely want to puke. His relatives are animals. She slides back into the house. Brenda looks at Sam.
Why didn't you say hello to them?
They didn't say hello to me.
Don't be smart. Brenda goes back in the house. Sam shakes her head in disbelief.
I have entered a dimension beyond all time and space....
Sam trudges up the stairs anxious for the solitude of her bedroom. She reaches the top of the stairs and throws up her free hand in dismay.

Sam's grandparents, Jim's parents, Howard and Dorothy Bak are changing out of their travel clothes. They're in thei early seventies. They're sweet and kind but pampered and particular. Dorothy's in her gigantic bra and slip. Howar in his undershorts, undershirt, socks and garters. They'r puttering around unpacking.
She turns slowly to try and sneak back down without getti nabbed by the grandparents. A creaky stair gives her away
Dorothy and Howard turn around. They're startled until they recognize Sam. Howard reaches for his pants.
Sam!
(to herself) Samantha....
How's my little pumpkin?
Fine, Grandpa. How are you guys? Howard gives her a hug and passes her to Dorothy who bear hugs her. Sam grimaces as she's engulfed in her grand- mother's arms.
You're sleeping up here?
(irritated) Your grandpa Fred jumped our claim on Sara's room.
Dorothy releases Sam. She steps back out of hugging range and discreetly smells her shoulder to see if Dorothy's le a noticeable scent.
Be fair, Howard. You got the garage for the Oldsmobile. Sam drops a major hint about her birthday.
It's a nice day isn't it? September fifteenth.
A little nippy, if you ask me.
I hope it isn't cold tomorrow. You know Ginny. She'll refuse to wear a hat and coat over her wedding dress. Sam's face drops as she realizes that they, too, have forgotten her birthday.
I'm going to set myself up in Mike's room.
Okay, sweetie. Grandpa and I look forward to a long, long visit with you.
(forces a smile) Aces.
Sam comes down from the third floor.
This has to be a joke. I swear to God.
Sara's door opens and Brenda's dad, Fred Addison, comes o He's a jolly, robust man in his late sixties. His fashion model is Sam Snead.
Hey! Hey! It's Sammy Baker Davis Jr.!
(unenthusiastic) Hi, Grandpa. Fred's a wise guy. An ancient ham whose sense of humor is completely lost on Sam.
Knock! Knock!
Who's there?
Who!
(weary of the hoary old joke) Who? Who? Fred leans back into Sara's room.
Helen? There's an owl out here in the hall. Fred snorts and grabs Sam. He tickles her. Sam loathes it. Helen Addison comes out of Sara's room. She's an attractive and somewhat chic older women.
Fred, you'll make her wet her pants tickling her like that!
Aw, come on, Helen! Helen swats his hand. He snorts again and releases Sam.
Let me look at you, Sam.
She pushes Sam back and examines her at arm's length.
(clicks . her tongue) Oh, my. (to Fred) Her little breasts have come in. Sam blanches with horror. Fred makes another limp joke.
I better go get my magnifying glass!
A typical boy's room with posters and sports equipment an bunk beds. Sam walks in, closes the door, walks over to the bed and flops down on the bottom bunk in exaggerated despair.
I can't believe my grandmother actually felt me up. She closes her eyes. A head pops up on the top bunk and looks over the side.
Her eyes are closed. She feels a presence. Her eyes open. We hear a Chinese gong.
is hanging over the top bunk, looking at her upside down. He's dopey-looking with big black rim glasses, and long, straight hair. His name is Long Duk Dong.
(thick accent) What's happening, hot stuff?
Brenda's dressed for the dinner at the club. She's puttering around the kitchen, cleaning up, checking the dinner in the oven. Mike's sitting at the kitchen table watching television.
Sam walks house has 31 61
His name is Long Duk Dong and he came down with Grandma and Grandpa Baker. He's an exchange student that's living with them.
He's completely bizarre.
(angry) He is not! He's a very sweet boy.
I hope you burn the mattress and sheets after he leaves. in, completely resigned to the fact that the gone crazy.
I don't suppose it makes any difference to you, but there's a very weird Chinese guy up in Mike's room.
Ginny dumped Rudy. He's her new fiance.
Mike! Stop it! (to Sam) Will you help the grandmothers with dinner?
(hinting again) Is there any reason I should stay home tonight?
I think it'd be nice if you visited with your grandparents and Long Duk Dong.
Who?
The weird Chinese guy in Mike's room.
(disappointed) I think I have a dance to go to.
Can you remember to turn off the stove in ten minutes?
I can remember lots of things. Brenda looks puzzled at Sam, then decides she doesn't hav the time to unravel teenage mysteries and exits. Sam sits down.
This is the single worst day of my entire life.
What are you bitching about? I have to sleep underneath a Chinaman named after a duck's dork.
(suspicious) Where am I sleeping?
(with sadistic glee) Sofa City, sweetheart. Sam drops her head to the table.
Ginny's getting dressed for the dinner at the club. She's in her panties and bra. Sam's laying on the bed looking a the wedding dress hanging on the open closet door. She toys with the lace.
Do you think Grandpa Fred's going to embarrass me?
I don't know why not. He does it to everybody else.
He asked me if Rudy was the oily variety bohunk.
(kidding) Is he? .

Don't be cute. I'm so paranoid. I know everybody'd be happier if I was marrying a white bread. Aunt Grace pulled me aside at the luncheon and told me that every family like Rudy's, no matter how straight, has a thug in it. She said it would be impos- sible to divorce him and live to enjoy it.
She's senile.

I really love Rudy. And he loves me totally. I've had guys who loved me, but Rudy is like flipped-out. Even after six months. Ginny's casual attitude toward romance reminds Sam of how romantically bankrupt her own life is. Ginny has long enjoyed an overabundance of boyfriends. She has no consideration of how Sam might feel.
(timidly) I think I'm in love. Ginny sits down next to Sam and puts on an annoying motherly front. She speaks to Sam like she's a child.

That's really sweet, Sam, but Rudy and my love isn't a going steady thing. It's mature, adult love. We're getting married. This is it. The big time. When your turn comes around, you'll understand what I'm saying.

She quickly refocuses the attention on herself. She stand up and models her full bust in the mirror on the back of the door. She drops the subject. Sam stands behind her and checks herself in the mirror.
You don't have to get married to be in love. Ginny sits down at her dressing table and begins her make
Of course not. But there's dif- ferent varieties of love. What you're experiencing is puppy love.
(offended) Thank you.
You're welcome. So. How long have you been in love? A day? A week? (pause) Ten minutes? Sam doesn't respond. She's angry at Ginny's insensitivity
How long? How serious?
(sheepishly) It hasn't really happened yet. -
You mean you're in love. Has he told you he loves you?
Not exactly.
Are you dating?
(reluctantly) No.
Well, are you doing anything? Sam shakes her head.
steaming hot quiche. Pull back to reveal Dong bent over t food, studying it. He looks up, his glasses steamed over. He's amazed and impressed by the quiche.
Very clever dinner. Appetizing food fit neatly into interesting round pie.
The grandparents, Mike, Sara, Sam and Dong are sitting at the dining room table with their TV dinners.
It's quiche.
(puzzled) How you spell?

You don't spell it, son, you eat it. He looks at Sam and rattles his dentures for her amusemen She's hardly amused. Dorothy doesn't take kindly to Fred' treatment of Dong. Dong smiles at Sam. She returns a polite smile.
(to Sam) Long Duk Dong's about your age, Sam. You two should have lots to chat about.
(cloying) I love visiting with Grandma and Grandpa and writing letters to my parents and pushing the lawn mowing machine so Grandpa's hernia is so much disturbed.
He also does the dishes and helps with the laundry.
Where Dong comes from, young people respect and admire senior citizens.
Sam rolls her eyes. Mike looks at her, motions to Long Du Dong and raises his eyebrows mockingly suggesting Sam mak play for Dong. She curls her lip at him and pushes back from the table.
Can I be excused?
(surprised) Where're you going?
I have a dance at school.
(disappointed) I thought we were going to make popcorn and play the Twister.
(bullshitting) This is an important dance. We're graded on it. For gym.
No kids still do the Watusi?
I do!
Wait a minute, Sam. I've got a wonderful idea! (to Dong, excited) Would you like to go to the dance with Sam? Sam's eyes bulge in horror. Dong snaps his fingers.
Super! Sam mouths a distraught "Oh, my God." Music comes up.
Dong's at the wheel. Sam's slumped down as far as she can get in the seat. She's wearing a skirt and blouse. Dentist office music is blasting and the windows are wide open.
This car rockets right along, huh? V-8, no monkey business! Sam nods. If she had an ounce more guts she'd throw herse out the door and die on the pavement.
I got a driver's license for United States two weeks ago. (holds up three fingers) First time I drive alone!
